Solan

Solan isn’t just a stop between Chandigarh and Shimla. It’s a district that has found its own balance; fairs and factories, classrooms and cantonments, temples and tea stalls. Mushrooms grow in labs, tomatoes ripen in fields, and deodar forests still guard the ridges. Solan moves forward, but it doesn’t forget its roots.

Our Hidden Favourites

  • Sherpa Eco Resort, Solan – A quiet hillside retreat where mornings start with mist and end with bonfire chatter.
  • Aunty ka Dhaba, Chail – No menus, just simple food made with love. You’ll remember her parathas longer than you expect.
  • Chai stall near Jatoli Temple – Tea that tastes better because of temple bells in the background.
  • Phantom Hill, Solan – A forgotten ridge with a view that feels like it’s yours alone.
  • Karol ka Tibba – A trek where the climb is tough, but the silence at the top teaches you something about yourself.
  • Kaali ka Tibba, Chail – A hilltop temple where the sky seems wider than anywhere else.

Towns & Villages

  • Solan City – Named after Mata Shoolini. Each June the Shoolini Fair turns the streets into a festival of devotion, music, and food. The old Mohan Meakin Brewery nearby still runs, a reminder of colonial times.
    Today Solan is called the Mushroom City of India and the City of Red Gold for its tomatoes.
  • Arki – Once the capital of the Baghal princely state. The Arki Fort still stands, and the Sair Fair draws crowds with folk songs and wrestling.
  • Kasauli – A British cantonment since 1842. Christ Church still rings its bells, and Monkey Point offers a view where the valley and sky meet.
  • Nalagarh – Known as the Gateway to Himachal. Its $15\text{th}$-century fort now welcomes guests, while the town thrives on orchards and the industrial belt.
  • Parwanoo – Orchard country at the border. The Timber Trail ropeway climbs from here into pine forests, and fruit shops line the road.
  • Chail – Home to the Chail Palace, the world’s highest cricket ground, and quiet deodar forests. Kaali Ka Tibba rises here, offering wide Himalayan views.
  • Baddi – The pharma hub, rows of factories powering the district’s economy.
  • Sabathu (Subathu) – An old cantonment town where the Gorkhas were first stationed in 1815. The fair here still brings locals together.
  • Barog – A misty railway stop with a famous tunnel. Fog and old stories linger here.
  • Dagshai – Once a TB sanatorium, now a school town. British graves and stone barracks remind you of another era.
  • Kandaghat – A small highway town on the way to Chail, with its own old Mughal tomb tucked nearby.
  • Waknaghat – Best known today for Jaypee University, a town of classrooms and young voices.

Culture & Festivals

  • Festivals & Fairs: Shoolini Fair, Sair Fair, Dussehra melas. Wrestling matches, folk songs, processions, and stalls.
  • Youth Energy: From blood donation camps to tree-planting drives, the student population keeps Solan lively.
  • Folk Traditions: Nati dance at melas, shawl weaving in villages, Pahari dialects spoken at tea stalls.
  • Everyday Life: Markets where everyone knows your name, evenings when different himachali dialects of greeting on every lip.

Education & Youth

  • Shoolini University brings students from across India.
  • Dr. Y.S. Parmar University at Nauni keeps Himachal’s horticulture heritage alive.
  • Jaypee University (Waknaghat) trains young engineers and coders.
  • Students bring their own rhythm: blood donation drives, debate competitions, cleanliness rallies, and music fests. Evenings spill into cafés and late-night walks, making the hills feel restless in the best way.

Our Stories

Exploring the majestic peaks of the Himalayas, capturing breathtaking moments.

Immersing ourselves in the rich culture and vibrant traditions of Himachal Pradesh.

Food & Markets

  • Mall Road, Solan: Mushroom patties, fresh bread, and the easy laughter of students.
  • Tibetan Market (Anand Complex): Jackets, shawls, and endless bargaining.
  • Kasauli Bazaar: Homemade jams and woollens stacked in tiny shops.
  • Parwanoo: Fruit mandi where apples and peaches pile up in crates.
  • Chail Bazaar: A snug stretch of stalls with woollens and pine-nut sweets.
  • Baddi & Nalagarh: Bazaars that smell of snacks and diesel — factory workers grabbing jalebis after their shifts.

Travel Basics

  • Getting there: Located on NH-5 (old Kalka–Shimla highway). Easily accessible by road from Chandigarh, Panchkula, Shimla, and Kalka. Nearest major railway station is Kalka; narrow-gauge trains connect to Solan.
  • Transport: Regular HRTC buses along the Kalka–Shimla route, with frequent stops at Solan, Dharampur, Kandaghat, and Parwanoo. Local taxis widely available in Solan town and tourist spots like Kasauli and Barog.
  • Connectivity: Good mobile coverage in towns; BSNL, Airtel, and Jio work reliably. ATMs available in Solan town, and major market areas.
  • Seasons:
    • Apr–Jun: Pleasant in hills, warm in lower belt; tourist rush toward Kasauli, Barog.
    • Jul–Aug: Monsoon showers, dense fog on higher roads (Kasauli–Mashobra belt).
    • Sep–Oct: Ideal weather, festive season, lush greenery and clear views.
    • Nov–Feb: Cool winters in town; higher areas like Kasauli and Barog can get frosty nights.
  • Monsoon note: Jul–Sep—fog reduces visibility on hilly curves; risk of minor landslides on Dharampur–Kasauli road.

Etiquette Note for Sacred Places & Water Bodies

  • For temples: Come clean. Avoid alcohol, meat/non-veg, and eggs before visiting.
  • Silence matters: Don’t blast music or turn temple surroundings into a picnic ground. Quiet is part of the experience.
  • Don’t litter:r Carry back everything you bring. Please don’t leave chip packets, bottles, diapers, pads, or plastics behind.
  • Respect water bodies: Stay away from streams, rivers, or ponds unless locals say it’s safe or respectful to enter. Never jump into sacred ponds or springs without permission. Some waters are reserved for rituals or for specific occasions.
  • Ask before you enter: Local guidance will help you avoid mistakes and keep you safe.
  • Women’s visit during periods: In many villages, customs suggest women avoid visiting sacred sites during menstruation. This isn’t about judgment but about following age-old traditions where the community sees these places as deeply charged. The idea is to approach them in a state of balance and respect, as locals believe certain energies are best met with clarity.
  • Leave lighter than you arrived: Your respect keeps the mountains alive for those who come after you.
